user.biography: Where great art and courageous conversations are catalysts for a more connected, civic, and empathetic world. We stand with Black Lives Matter.

node.text:
We’re proud to be supporting @nycnext and New York City in their efforts to help rebuild the city we love most 🗽⁠
⁠
Enjoy this special rendition of a @BillyJoel classic, shot in iconic locations across the five boroughs—including the Brooklyn Museum📍⁠
⁠
Go to NYCNext.org or for a list of volunteer opportunities and ways to support local businesses across industries, organizations, and neighborhoods. #NYCNextStateofMind

node.title: NYCNext: New York State of Mind

node.text:
If this past year taught us anything it's that we can accomplish so much more through collaboration with our neighbors and partners. In the final episode of our #YearattheMuseum series, we reconnected with a few of our recent community-based partners @soulsinfocus, @tcahnyc, @f.o.o.dfoundation, and @grandmashandsinc to ask them how we can continue to show up in the years to come.⁠

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow, ft. @lavalshante, Director of Marketing and @keonnah, Director of DEIA.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Community Partnerships

node.text:
So much happens behind-the-scenes of a Museum, and even more so within a conservation lab. Tune in to our latest video with Lisa Bruno, Carol Lee Shen Chief Conservator, for a peek into how we care for our collections—from reversing outdated treatments to stories behind recent projects and what took place when the Museum shut down due to COVID-19. #AYearattheMuseum

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠

Treatments featured: William Williams, Deborah Hall (1766) ⇨ Cecily Brown (British, born 1969). Triumph of the Vanities II, 2018. Purchase gift of John and Barbara Vogelstein in honor of Anne Pasternak © artist or artist's estate⁠ ⇨ Assyrian reliefs, Neo-Assyrian Period, reign of Ashur-nasir-pal II, circa 883–859 B.C.E. Funding for the conservation of the Assyrian Reliefs was generously provided through a grant from the @bankofamerica Art Conservation Project.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Collection Care

node.text:
The role of a curator is a lot more complex than you may think! Hear from Catherine Futter, our Senior Curator of Decorative Arts, on how she accesses the collection and works collaboratively with nearly every department across the Museum. You’ll also get a peek into our new exhibition Design: 1880 to Now, which highlights some of the most important design movements during that period.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
⁠Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ ⁠#AYearAtTheMuseum⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: ⁠Notes from a Curator⁠

node.text:
What did you miss about museums during shutdown? It's been wonderful to safely welcome visitors back to our galleries, and we thank each and every one of them for taking the time to visit! ⁠
⁠
Now more than ever, the strength of our #BKMMembers community is our greatest asset. We hope you continue your support of the Museum by becoming a Member! We now offer discounted 6-month Memberships—learn more at http://bit.ly/bkmmembers (link in bio).⁠
⁠
Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ #ayearatthemuseum

node.title: It’s so good to see you!

node.text: You're tuned in to Screen Time where today Adama Delphine Fawundu (@adamadelphine) discusses “the cleanse” with curator Carmen Hermo (@chermosa). View the video in full on our plaza as part of our Art on the Stoop #SunsetScreenings series, showing each Wednesday, Thursday, and Sunday through November 8, starting at 5pm. ⁠⠀

node.text: Today Hank Willis Thomas (@hankwillisthomas) is joined by Bayeté Ross Smith (@bayetekenan) to discuss the transmedia project “Question Bridge: Black Males” and how it connects to today. 🙏🏾

node.title: Screen Time with Hank Willis Thomas and Bayeté Ross Smith

node.text: Today artist Liz Johnson Artur (@lizjohnsonartur) joins Drew Sawyer (@drewmsawyer), Phillip Leonian and Edith Rosenbaum Leonian Curator of Photography, for a chat about Artur’s work, AfroRussia which is on view as part of our #SunsetScreenings series. We hope you enjoy this brief chat, and are able to check out AfroRussia outside on the Museum plaza through Sunday, October 11. Head to link in bio to find the series' details and schedule.

node.title: Screen Time with Liz Johnson Artur

node.text: Today artist Marilyn Minter (@marilynminter) joins Catherine Morris (@catherinejanetmorris), Sackler Senior Curator for the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, for a chat about Minter’s work, including Smash (2014) which is on view as part of our #SunsetScreenings series. Head to link in bio to find out more about the series.

node.text:
The Campaign Against Hunger’s (@tcahnyc) mission is to empower our neighbors to live healthier, more productive and self-sufficient lives by increasing access to safe, nutritious food and resources. 60% of the clients they serve are from historically undercounted communities. When you fill out the census, you’re advocating for more federal funding towards organizations like this. Take the time today and complete your census at my2020census.gov. #GetCountedNYC⁠⠀
⁠⠀
And for our community members in need—a friendly reminder that our weekly food distribution with @tcahnyc takes place in our sculpture garden behind the Museum, every Monday at 4pm, on a first-come, first-serve basis. We recommend arriving early to receive a ticket in line. If you have any questions, email us at healthymeals@brooklynmuseum.org.⁠⠀

node.text:
⁠The census determines billions of dollars in funding for our schools, health care, jobs programs, housing, transportation, and so many other vital services. Census numbers in central Brooklyn, Bed-Stuy and Crown Heights are substantially lower than other parts of Brooklyn. We and Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr. (@rcornegyjr) want to change that. Make sure to get counted so we can get a fair share of resources for our community.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Fill out the Census now through September 30 at my2020census.gov and #GetCountedNYC

node.title: Census 2020: Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr.

node.text:
In our fall studio art class, Drawing and Painting: The Color of Change, teens will develop their own distinct artistic style while finding inspiration in the Obama portraits and engaging in conversations on racial equity through contemporary art. On Sunday afternoons, from October 3–December 12, students will learn new techniques in color theory, underpainting, and paint mixing and paint portraits across a spectrum of hues.  Head to link in bio to register or apply for a scholarship.⁠
⁠
Photo: Brittney Najar, 2016

node.text:
It's time to take an Art Break with our partners @MTV! This week's video, G.O.L. by @chrisunkim is an animation in the same style as the Atari game Breakout and investigates sign language interpretation and the metaphorical echo created by the interpreter. From her own worlds: “An echo is what happens when a sound hits a surface and repeats, sometimes from a different direction, and sometimes compromised or distorted. This video considers how sign language interpreters process information and how Deaf people receive information from and through these interpreters. Interpreters repeat what they hear, enacting a constant echo of series of visual echos.”
 ⁠
Check back on Sunday for the third installment of Art Breaks! And don’t forget to check out the full length videos on MTV and in Times Square at 1515 Broadway.⁠
 ⁠
Animation by @janjoostverhoef⁠
Sound by @matt.karmil

node.text:
👋 Fresno! Our acclaimed exhibition Nobody Promised You Tomorrow: Art 50 Years After Stonewall is now on view at the Center for Creativity and the Arts at Fresno State (@ccafresnostate) until October 31. Featuring all of the artists from our original presentation as well as new additions, the exhibition explores the profound legacy of the 1969 Stonewall Uprising within art and visual culture today. Nobody Promised You Tomorrow aims to contextualize the Stonewall Uprising beyond the protests, exploring the ways in which everyday acts and care sustain communities and public activism. If you have a friend in Fresno who you think will enjoy this show, tag them and tell them to check it out! ​#BKMTours⁠
⁠
Elektra KB (Colombian). Protest Sign II, 2017. Textile, felt, thread. Courtesy of the artist. © Elektra KB

node.text:
This week’s #SupportBrooklyn highlights String Thing Studio, the only Black-owned yarn shop in NYC! Located in Park Slope, @stringthingstudio is a yarn lover’s haven and a welcoming space for creatives of all types. Read more on them below! 

“Whether you knit, crochet, weave or macramé, you will experience creativity in every aspect at String Thing Studio. From the beautiful array of yarns for a wide range of tastes, to the classes and events offered to educate and inspire. I knew when I decided to open String Thing Studio it couldn't be anywhere else but Brooklyn. Park Slope is my home! Prospect Park is my backyard! We've made lifelong friends here. We have witnessed the renaissance that Brooklyn has gone through over the past 17 years and I still love it and find it hard to imagine living anywhere else. Everyone that comes into String Thing Studio brings such a warm energy and love spending time with each other. We have a cross section of people that consider String Thing Studio their home. When the pandemic hit, and we had to close, it was hard on us but even more so on our community. But, in classic String Thing Style, they rallied behind EVERYTHING that I did to stay afloat and get back open. I love how they love this shop and we love them right back.”

String Thing Studio
Website: stringthingstudio.com
Facebook: @StringThingStudio 
Instagram: @stringthingstudio
Location: 54 7th Avenue Brooklyn, NY 11217

node.text:
The Obama portraits make their Brooklyn debut on August 27! From the moment they were unveiled, @kehindewiley’s portrait of President @barackobama and @asherald’s portrait of former First Lady @michelleobama have inspired an unprecedented response from the public. Experience these vibrant and groundbreaking depictions of American leadership, on view August 27–October 24. Reservations are required. Visit link in bio to plan your visit.⁠
⁠
And, stop by our plaza on Saturday, August 28 from 4–8 pm to celebrate the exhibition's opening! Enjoy music by @burntsugararkestra and @niarasterling, poetry readings presented by @cavecanempoets, and art-making with @coolculture and BkM educators. Plus get your photograph taken by @soulsinfocus and stop by the @brooklyn.pop.up market, which is spotlighting local Black vendors. This outdoor event is free, but please head to link in bio to RSVP.  #ObamaPortraitsTour

node.text:
"Tête de Femme" is one of the first that Edmonds made with a decorative African object, which he borrowed from the home of a family in Brooklyn. As in his Du-Rags series, Edmonds photographed these objects with young Black and queer-identifying people from his own creative community in New York. Edmonds says, “I was drawn to the objects because of how they were stylized and how that stylizing spoke to a wider view of an ‘African’ vernacular of Black homes in America.”⁠
⁠
Like many of his works, this photograph is layered with art historical references that reimagine the reception of African art in Europe and the United States. The title Tête de Femme—French for “head of a woman”—has often been used in European art to describe portraits of women, and the pairing of a woman’s face with an African mask evokes American Surrealist artist Man Ray’s famous 1926 photograph Noire et blanche, which juxtaposes the face of white model Kiki (Alice Prin) with a Baule-style mask from Côte d’Ivoire.⁠
⁠
Discover this work and more in the exhibition John Edmonds: A Sidelong Glance on view through September 26.⁠
⁠
John Edmonds (American, born 1989). Tête de Femme, 2018. Archival pigment photograph. Courtesy the artist. @uovo.art

node.text:
Young artists are invited to experience art like never before in our fall studio art classes! From painting and drawing to sculpture and animation, there's a class for every budding artist! Read more about our classes below, and head to link in bio to register. As always, scholarships are available for all youth classes.⁠
⁠
⭐⭐ For Ages 6–7 ⭐⭐⁠
➡️ Painting: From Pharaohs to Presidents⁠: Learn the elements of art and explore how different cultures represent their leaders.⁠
➡️ Mixed-Media: Snap, Cut, Glue⁠: Explore Andy Warhol: Revelation and create your own works of art.⁠
⁠
⭐⭐ For Ages 8–10 ⭐⭐⁠
➡️ Sculpture: Build and Transform⁠: Learn how to make 3-D artworks with clay, plaster, and wire.⁠
➡️ Drawing and Painting: Shades of Hope⁠: Visit the Obama portraits, then unleash your creativity on canvas.⁠
⁠
⁠
⭐⭐ For Ages 11–13 ⭐⭐⁠
➡️ Digital Art: Copy/Paste⁠: Develop your skills in photography, digital drawing, and animation.⁠
➡️ Portfolio Development⁠: Learn what it takes to make it into art-focused high schools and create portfolio quality drawings and sculptures.

node.text:
LAUNCHING TODAY 🚀 We are excited to take part in the revival of @MTV’s Art Breaks! Together we commissioned five international artists to create new videos that will air on MTV and in Times Square at 1515 Broadway every day, on every hour. A new video will be released every Sunday through September 12 leading up to the MTV @vmas hosted this year in Brooklyn.⁠
⁠
This week, we’re featuring @nicholasgalanin’s work Ix̱six̱án ax̱ tʼukanéiyi (2021). Meaning “I love you, my baby,” this video centers Indigenous families and communities through a sampling of Tlingit words of love and care spoken to an Indigenous child. Rejecting the false historical narratives and generational trauma inflicted by settler-colonialism, this video instead focuses on love, safety, and connection.
